title: Quiz 1: July 2014 Licensure Exam
description: July 2014 Licensure Examination for Admission to the Register of Community Health Nurses. Covers Community Health, Communicable Diseases, and Administration.

questions.question: An example of a disease that does not pass from human to human is:
questions.explanation: Tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani spores found in the environment (soil, dust). It is non-communicable, meaning it cannot be transmitted from person to person. TB and Diphtheria are communicable.
questions.hint: Think of a disease caused by spores in the soil rather than droplets or contact.

questions.question: In the treatment of tuberculosis 'DOT' means:

options.text: Patient getting TB treatment as close to home as possible
Patient adheres to treatment during the intensive phase only
Directly observed treatment with weekly monitoring
Patient takes every drug dosage under supervision during the intensive phase

questions.explanation: DOTS (Directly Observed Treatment, Short-course) involves a health worker observing the patient swallow their medication to ensure adherence, particularly during the intensive phase.
questions.hint: The 'O' stands for Observed.

questions.question: All health care services and activities within the district are monitored and supervised by the:
questions.explanation: The District Health Management Team (DHMT) is responsible for the overall planning, monitoring, and supervision of health services in the district.
questions.hint: It requires a team approach for district-level supervision.

questions.question: Triaging may best be defined as the process of:

options.text: Assessing all incoming casualties of a disaster
Initiating diagnostic measures for casualties of a disaster
Determining the urgency of need of care for casualties of a disaster
Setting priorities and assigning urgency ratings for casualties of a disaster

questions.explanation: Triage (from French 'trier', to sort) is the process of sorting patients based on the severity of their condition to set priorities for treatment.
questions.hint: Think about sorting and prioritizing.

questions.question: Non-organic growth failure (failure to thrive) in a child may be attributed to:

options.text: A poor mother-child bond of attachment
Altered physiology due to improper feeding

questions.explanation: Non-organic failure to thrive is caused by psychosocial factors, such as emotional deprivation or poor attachment, rather than a medical/physiological condition.
questions.hint: Look for the cause that is psychological or social, not physical.

questions.question: The acid-generating bacterium in our mouth that is the most common cause of tooth decay (dental caries) is the:
questions.explanation: Streptococcus mutans metabolizes sugars to produce acid, which demineralizes tooth enamel leading to caries.
questions.hint: Mutans sounds like mutant, causing change/decay.

questions.question: The term 'role' may be defined as:

options.text: Community's expectation of a trained person
Legal and moral binding of a professional
Capacity to run health care activities
Activities one is expected to perform as a professional

questions.explanation: A role refers to the set of behaviors, activities, and responsibilities expected of a person holding a specific position.
questions.hint: It relates to what you DO in your position.

questions.question: Currently in Kenya the problems associated with old age are made worse by the:

options.text: Inability to acquire new marketable skills
Disintegration of traditional social support systems

questions.explanation: The collapse of the extended family structure (traditional support system) due to urbanization has exacerbated the vulnerability of the elderly.
questions.hint: Think about what used to protect the elderly in traditional society but is now fading.

questions.question: A major cause of 'missed opportunity' in the immunization programme is:

options.text: Use of vaccines that have lost potency
High drop-out of immunizable target group

questions.explanation: Missed opportunities occur when eligible clients attend a facility but don't get vaccinated. Stock-outs are a major logistical cause.
questions.hint: You cannot give what you do not have.

questions.question: The process in community diagnosis in which data is separated and categorized in order to help one understand its meaning is known as data:
questions.explanation: Data analysis is the process of inspecting, cleaning, transforming, and modeling data (separating and categorizing) to discover useful information.
questions.hint: This step comes after collection but before presentation.

questions.question: Vitamins found in the watery parts of the foods we eat:

options.text: Vit K, Niacin, Riboflavin, panthonic acid
Pantothenic acid, Thiamine, Pyridoxine, Vit E
Vit K, Pantothenic acid, Thiamine, Pyridoxine

questions.explanation: Water-soluble vitamins include the B-complex group (Thiamine, Riboflavin, Folate, B12/Cyanocobalamin) and Vitamin C. Vitamins A, D, E, and K are fat-soluble.
questions.hint: Look for the option that contains ONLY B-vitamins or C. Avoid A, D, E, K.

questions.question: Essential amino acids can be defined as amino acids that:

options.text: Cannot be made by the body
Body can make if nitrogen is available
Are unique in their primary structure
Are the basic building blocks of proteins

questions.explanation: Essential amino acids cannot be synthesized by the body and must be obtained from the diet.
questions.hint: They are 'essential' because you MUST eat them.

questions.question: The dosage of drugs in primary level ARV prophylaxis for prevention of mother-to-child transmission of the HIV is (Historical Protocol):

options.text: Nevirapine (NVP) 200mg to mother at onset of labour, infant NVP 2mg/kg as soon as possible within 72 hours
Nevirapine 200mg to mother during labour, infant NVP 2mg/kg immediately after birth plus 4 weeks of AZT
AZT 300mg BD plus NVP 200mg to mother during labour, infant 2mg/kg after birth plus AZT 4mg/kg BD
AZT 600mg to mother at onset of labour, infant NVP 2mg/kg immediately after birth

questions.explanation: This describes the classic single-dose Nevirapine regimen which was a primary intervention historically.
questions.hint: Look for the single-dose NVP regimen for both mother and infant.

questions.question: Water-related diseases include:
questions.explanation: This option covers water-borne (Cholera), water-based (Schistosomiasis), and water-related vector (Malaria) diseases.
questions.hint: Identify the option with three distinct types: mosquito-borne, snail-borne, and bacteria-ingested.

questions.question: When health care is geographically, financially and culturally within easy reach to the entire community the service is said to be:
questions.explanation: Accessibility is a broad concept that encompasses geographic reach, financial affordability, and cultural acceptability.
questions.hint: This term covers physical, economic, and social reach.

questions.question: The purpose of a screening test is to:

options.text: Detect persons with risk factors of sub-clinical disease
Check whether a population is at risk of a disease
Collect the data for a mass campaign

questions.explanation: Screening is designed to identify unrecognized disease or risk factors in an apparently healthy population (sub-clinical phase) for early intervention. It is not diagnostic.
questions.hint: Screening finds potential problems before symptoms appear.

questions.question: Herd immunity may be said to exist in a community when:

options.text: Both dead and live antigens are used to immunize
Vaccination is stopped in a community that has been well vaccinated
The incidence of the disease decrease to a very low level
A high percentage of people are immune to an infection

questions.explanation: Herd immunity exists when a high proportion of the population is immune, providing indirect protection to the susceptible few.
questions.hint: It relies on the 'herd' (the majority) being protected.

questions.question: Emergency hormonal contraception is usually effective following unprotected sex when taken within a period of:
questions.explanation: Standard Levonorgestrel ECPs are most effective if taken within 72 hours (3 days).
questions.hint: 3 days.

questions.question: Evaluate the following statements. Statement A: 'Ascribed status is position gained by merit.' Statement B: 'Gender equity means men and women are treated exactly the same by law.'

options.text: Statement A is True, B is False
Statement A is False, B is True

questions.explanation: Statement A is False: Ascribed status is assigned at birth (e.g., race, sex), not earned. Statement B is False: That describes Equality. Equity refers to fairness, which may involve different treatment to achieve equal outcomes.
questions.hint: Ascribed means given, not earned. Equity means fairness, not sameness.

questions.question: Match the medical terms/concepts with their correct descriptions:

pairs.right: Detects disease early and treats promptly to cure
Foetal deaths from 28 weeks + infant deaths under 7 days

questions.explanation: Secondary prevention focuses on early diagnosis and treatment. Perinatal mortality covers late fetal death through early neonatal life. Measles presents with cough (3 Cs). Rubella lacks Koplik's spots.
questions.hint: Measles has cough; Rubella does not have the white mouth spots.

questions.question: Match the sampling method to its definition:

pairs.right: Every member has a known, non-zero chance of selection (Random)
Selection based on subjective judgment, not random selection

questions.explanation: Probability sampling relies on random selection allowing generalization. Non-probability relies on researcher judgment.
questions.hint: Probability involves 'chance' or 'randomness'.

questions.question: Match the disease to its causative organism:
questions.explanation: Specific causative agents: Leishmania donovani (Visceral Leishmaniasis), P. falciparum (Malaria), S. typhi (Typhoid), Y. pestis (Plague).
questions.hint: Typhoid -> Typhi. Plague -> Pestis.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of the problem-solving process in sequential order:
questions.explanation: The logical flow is: Define -> Analyze -> Plan/Alternatives -> Select -> Act -> Check/Evaluate.
questions.hint: You must know what the problem is before you can analyze it.

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical benefits of Anti-Retroviral Treatment (ARV)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: ARVs suppress the virus, restore immunity, prevent OIs, and reduce transmission, but they do not cure the infection completely.
questions.hint: ARVs manage the condition but do not eliminate the virus entirely.

questions.question: Order the steps of the hospital waste management process from start to finish:
questions.explanation: Waste must first be separated, then collected/stored, transported, treated (made safe), and finally disposed of.
questions.hint: It starts where the waste is created and ends in the pit/landfill.

questions.question: Select the activities carried out during school health services: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: School health focuses on screening, prevention (deworming/vaccines), education, and maintaining a safe environment. Major treatments are referred.
questions.hint: Think preventive and promotive, not complex curative.

questions.question: Which of the following are functions of an occupational health nurse? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Providing first aid for work injuries

questions.explanation: Occupational health nurses focus on the workplace: surveillance, risk assessment, first aid, and records relevant to worker health.
questions.hint: Focus on the 'workplace' setting.

questions.question: Arrange the stages of the Hookworm lifecycle in the correct order:
questions.explanation: Eggs hatch -> Larvae mature in soil -> Penetrate skin -> Travel to lungs -> Coughed up and swallowed -> Mature in gut.
questions.hint: They start in soil, enter skin, go to lungs, then gut.

questions.question: Select the correct considerations for preparing an immunization session: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Calculate target population to determine session frequency
Condition ice packs before putting them in the vaccine carrier
Arrange the area for unidirectional flow (Waiting -> Screening -> Injection)
Keep vaccines in direct sunlight to warm them up
Ensure safety boxes are within arm's reach

questions.explanation: Preparation involves calculating targets, proper cold chain (conditioning ice packs, no sun), and safe ergonomic layout (safety boxes, one-way flow).
questions.hint: Cold chain and safety are priorities.

questions.question: Identify the correct features and management steps for Acute Meningococcal Meningitis: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Stiffness of the neck and severe headache

questions.explanation: Meningitis presents with fever, stiff neck, headache, and rash. Management requires isolation and immediate IV antibiotics.
questions.hint: Think of the classic signs: stiff neck, rash. Management is urgent.
